abstract_sentences.1: We present a visually grounded model of speech perception which projects spoken utterances and images to a joint semantic space.
abstract_sentences.2: We use a multi-layer recurrent highway network to model the temporal nature of spoken speech, and show that it learns to extract both form and meaningbased linguistic knowledge from the input signal.
abstract_sentences.3: We carry out an in-depth analysis of the representations used by different components of the trained model and show that encoding of semantic aspects tends to become richer as we go up the hierarchy of layers, whereas encoding of formrelated aspects of the language input tends to initially increase and then plateau or decrease.

https://doi.org/10.18653/v1/P17-1057  1 Introduction  Speech recognition is one of the success stories of language technology.
body_sentences.2: It works remarkably well in a range of practical settings.
body_sentences.3: However, this success relies on the use of very heavy supervision where the machine is fed thousands of hours of painstakingly transcribed audio speech signal.
body_sentences.4: Humans are able to learn to recognize and understand speech from notably weaker and noisier supervision: they manage to learn to extract structure and meaning from speech by simply being exposed to utterances situated and grounded in their daily sensory experience.
body_sentences.5: Modeling and emulating this remarkable skill has been the goal of numerous studies; however in the overwhelming majority of cases researchers used severely simplified settings where either the language input or the extralinguistic sensory input, or both, are small scale and symbolically represented.
body_sentences.6: Section 2 provides a brief overview of this research.
body_sentences.7: More recently several lines of work have moved towards more realistic inputs while modeling or emulating language acquisition in a grounded setting.
body_sentences.8: Gelderloos and Chrupała (2016) use the image captioning dataset MS COCO (Lin et al., 2014) to mimic the setting of grounded language learning: the sensory input consists of images of natural scenes, while the language input are phonetically transcribed descriptions of these scenes.
body_sentences.9: The use of such moderately large and low-level data allows the authors to train a multi-layer recurrent neural network model, and to explore the nature and localization of the emerging hierarchy of linguistic representations learned in the process.
body_sentences.10: Furthermore, in a series of recent studies Harwath and Glass (2015); Harwath et al.
body_sentences.11: (2016); Harwath and Glass (2017) use image captioning datasets to model learning to understand spoken language from visual context with convolutional neural network models.
body_sentences.12: Finally, there is a small but growing body of work dedicated to elucidating the nature of representations learned by neural networks from language data (see Section 2.2 for a brief overview).
body_sentences.13:
In the current work we build on these three strands of research and contribute the following advances:
• We use a multi-layer gated recurrent neural network to properly model the temporal nature of speech signal and substantially improve performance compared to the convolutional architecture from Harwath and Glass (2015); • We carry out an in-depth analysis of the representations used by different components of the trained model and correlate them to representations learned by a text-based model and to human patterns of judgment on linguistic stimuli.
body_sentences.14: This analysis is especially novel for a model with speech signal as input.
body_sentences.15:
The general pattern of findings in our analysis is
613
as follows: The model learns to extract from the acoustic input both form-related and semanticsrelated information, and encodes it in the activations of the hidden layers.
body_sentences.16: Encoding of semantic aspects tends to become richer as we go up the hierarchy of layers.
body_sentences.17: Meanwhile, encoding of formrelated aspects of the language input, such as utterance length or the presence of specific words, tends to initially increase and then decay.
body_sentences.18: We release the code for our models and analyses as open source, available at https://github.com/gchrupala/visually-groundedspeech.
body_sentences.19: We also release a dataset of synthetically spoken image captions based on MS COCO, available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.400926.
body_sentences.20: 2 Related work  Children learn to recognize and assign meaning to words from continuous perceptual data in extremely noisy context.
body_sentences.21: While there have been many computational studies of human word meaning acquisition, they typically make strong simplifying assumptions about the nature of the input.
body_sentences.22: Often language input is given in the form of word symbols, and the context consists of a set of symbols representing possible referents (e.g.
body_sentences.23: Siskind, 1996; Frank et al., 2007; Fazly et al., 2010).
body_sentences.24: In contrast, several studies presented models that learn from sensory rather than symbolic input, which is rich with regards to the signal itself, but very limited in scale and variation (e.g.
body_sentences.25: Roy and Pentland, 2002; Yu and Ballard, 2004; Lazaridou et al., 2016).
body_sentences.26: 2.1 Multimodal language acquisition  Chrupała et al.
body_sentences.27: (2015) introduce a model that learns to predict the visual context from image captions.
body_sentences.28: The model is trained on image-caption pairs from MSCOCO (Lin et al., 2014), capturing both rich visual input as well as larger scale input, but the language input still consists of word symbols.
body_sentences.29: Gelderloos and Chrupała (2016) propose a similar architecture that instead takes phonemelevel transcriptions as language input, thereby incorporating the word segmentation problem into the learning task.
body_sentences.30: In this work, we introduce an architecture that learns from continuous speech and images directly.
body_sentences.31: This work is related to research on visual grounding of language.
body_sentences.32:
The field is large and growing, with most work dedicated to the ground-
ing of written text, particularly in image captioning tasks (see Bernardi et al.
body_sentences.34: However, learning to ground language to visual information is also interesting from an automatic speech recognition point of view.
body_sentences.35: Potentially, ASR systems could be trained from naturally co-occurring visual context information, without the need for extensive manual annotation – a particularly promising prospect for speech recognition in low-resource languages.
body_sentences.36: There have been several attempts along these lines.
body_sentences.38: (2014) present a method of learning to recognize spoken words in isolation from cooccurrence with image fragments.
body_sentences.39: Harwath and Glass (2015) present a model that learns to map pre-segmented spoken words in sequence to aspects of the visual context, while in Harwath and Glass (2017) the model also learns to recognize words in the unsegmented signal.
body_sentences.40: Most closely related to our work is that of Harwath et al.
body_sentences.41: (2016), as it presents an architecture that learns to project images and unsegmented spoken captions to the same embedding space.
body_sentences.42: The sentence representation is obtained by feeding the spectrogram to a convolutional network.
body_sentences.43: The architecture is trained on crowd-sourced spoken captions for images from the Places dataset (Zhou et al., 2014), and evaluated on image search and caption retrieval.
body_sentences.44: Unfortunately this dataset is not currently available and we were thus unable to directly compare the performance of our model to Harwath et al.
body_sentences.46: We do compare to Harwath and Glass (2015) which was tested on a public dataset.
body_sentences.47: We make different architectural choices, as our models are based on recurrent highway networks (Zilly et al., 2016).
body_sentences.48: As in human cognition, speech is processed incrementally.
body_sentences.49: This also allows our architecture to integrate information sequentially from speech of arbitrary duration.
body_sentences.50: 2.2 Analysis of neural representations  While analysis of neural methods in NLP is often limited to evaluation of the performance on the training task, recently methods have been introduced to peek inside the black box and explore what it is that enables the model to perform the task.
body_sentences.51: One approach is to look at the contribution of specific parts of the input, or specific units in the model, to final representations or decisions.
body_sentences.53:
(2016) propose omission scores, a method to estimate the contribution of input tokens to the fi-
nal representation by removing them from the input and comparing the resulting representations to the ones generated by the original input.
body_sentences.54: In a similar approach, Li et al.
body_sentences.55: (2016) study the contribution of individual input tokens as well as hidden units and word embedding dimensions by erasing them from the representation and analyzing how this affects the model.
body_sentences.58: (2016) use visualization techniques for fine-grained analysis of GRU and LSTM models for ASR.
body_sentences.59: Visualization of input and forget gate states allows Miao et al.
body_sentences.60: (2016) to make informed adaptations to gated recurrent architectures, resulting in more efficiently trainable models.
body_sentences.62: (2016) visualize qualitative differences between LSTM- and GRUbased architectures, regarding the encoding of information, as well as how it is processed through time.
body_sentences.63: We specifically study linguistic properties of the information encoded in the trained model.
body_sentences.65: (2016) introduce prediction tasks to analyze information encoded in sentence embeddings about word order, sentence length, and the presence of individual words.
body_sentences.66: We use related techniques to explore encoding of aspects of form and meaning within components of our stacked architecture.
body_sentences.67: 3 Models  We use a multi-layer, gated recurrent neural network (RHN) to model the temporal nature of speech signal.
body_sentences.68: Recurrent neural networks are designed for modeling sequential data, and gated variants (GRUs, LSTMs) are widely used with speech and text in both cognitive modeling and engineering contexts.
body_sentences.69: RHNs are a simple generalization of GRU networks such that the transform between time points can consist of several steps.
body_sentences.70: Our multimodal model projects spoken utterances and images to a joint semantic space.
body_sentences.71: The idea of projecting different modalities to a shared semantic space via a pair of encoders has been used in work on language and vision (among them Vendrov et al.
body_sentences.73: The core idea is to encourage inputs representing the same meaning in different modalities to end up nearby, while maintaining a distance from unrelated inputs.
body_sentences.74: The model consists of two parts: an utterance encoder, and an image encoder.

body_sentences.94: 4 Experiments  Our main goal is to analyze the emerging representations from different components of the model and to examine the linguistic knowledge they encode.
body_sentences.95: For this purpose, we employ a number of tasks that cover the spectrum from fully formbased to fully semantic.
body_sentences.96: In Section 4.2 we assess the effectiveness of our architecture by evaluating it on the task of ranking images given an utterance.
body_sentences.98: In Sections 4.3 and 4.4 we define auxiliary tasks to investigate to what extent the network encodes information about the surface form of an utterance from the speech input.
body_sentences.99: In Section 4.5 and 4.6 we focus on where semantic information is encoded in the model.

In the analyses, we use the following features: Utterance embeddings: the weighted sum of the
unit activations on the last layer, as calculated by Equation (3).
body_sentences.101: Average unit activations: hidden layer activations averaged over time and L2-normalized for each hidden layer.
body_sentences.102: Average input vectors: the MFCC vectors averaged over time.
body_sentences.103: We use this feature to examine how much information can be extracted from the input signal only.
body_sentences.104: 4.1 Data  For the experiments reported in the remainder of the paper we use two datasets of images with spoken captions.
body_sentences.105: 4.1.1 Flickr8K  The Flickr8k Audio Caption Corpus was constructed by having crowdsource workers read aloud the captions in the original Flickr8K corpus (Hodosh et al., 2013).
body_sentences.106: For details of the data collection procedure refer to Harwath and Glass (2015).
body_sentences.107: The datasets consist of 8,000 images, each image with five descriptions.
body_sentences.108: One thousand images are held out for validation, and another one thousand for the final test set.
body_sentences.109: We use the splits provided by (Karpathy and Fei-Fei, 2015).
body_sentences.110: The image features come from the final fully connect layer of VGG-16 (Simonyan and Zisserman, 2014) pre-trained on Imagenet (Russakovsky et al., 2014).
body_sentences.111: We generate the input signal as follows: we extract 12-dimensional mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCC) plus log of the total energy.

body_sentences.148: 4.3 Predicting utterance length  Our first auxiliary task is to predict the length of the utterance, using the features explained at the beginning of Section 4.
body_sentences.149: Since the length of an utterance directly corresponds to how long it takes to articulate, we also use the number of time steps5 as a feature and expect it to provide the upper bound for our task, especially for synthetic speech.
body_sentences.150: We use a Ridge Regression model for predicting utterance length using each set of features.
body_sentences.151: The model is trained on 80% of the sentences in the validation set, and tested on the remaining 20%.
body_sentences.152: For all features regularization penalty α = 1.0 gave the best results.
body_sentences.153: Figure 4 shows the results for this task on human speech from Flickr8K and synthetic speech from COCO.
body_sentences.154: With the exception of the average input vectors for Flickr8K, all features can explain a high proportion of variance in the predicted utterance length.
body_sentences.155: The pattern observed for the two datasets is slightly different: due to the systematic conversion of words to synthetic speech in COCO, using the number of time steps for this dataset yields the highest R2.
body_sentences.156: However, this feature is not as informative for predicting the utterance length in Flickr8K due to noise and variation in human speech, and is in fact outperformed by some of the features extracted from the model.
body_sentences.157: Also, the input vectors from COCO are much more informative than Flickr8K due to larger quantity and simpler structure of the speech signal.
body_sentences.158: However, in both datasets the best (non-ceiling) performance is obtained by using average unit activations from the hidden layers (layer 2 for COCO, and layers 3 and 4 for Flickr8K).
body_sentences.159: These features outperform utterance embeddings, which are optimized according to the visual grounding objective of the model and most probably learn to ignore the superficial characteristics of the utterance that do not contribute to matching the corresponding image.
body_sentences.160: Note that the performance on COCO plateaus after the second layer, which might suggest that form-based knowledge is learned by lower layers.
body_sentences.161: Since Flickr8K is much smaller in size, the stabilising happens later in layer 3.
body_sentences.163: 4.4 Predicting word presence  Results from the previous experiment suggest that our model acquires information about higher level building blocks (words) in the continuous speech signal.
body_sentences.164: Here we explore whether it can detect the presence or absence of individual words in an utterance.
body_sentences.165: We formulate detecting a word in an utterance as a binary classification task, for which we use a multi-layer perceptron with a single hidden layer of size 1024, optimized by Adam.
body_sentences.166: The input to the model is a concatenation of the feature vector representing an utterance and the one representing a target word.
body_sentences.167: We again use utterance embeddings, average unit activations on each layer, and average input vectors as features, and represent each target word as a vector of MFCC features extracted from the audio signal synthetically produced for that word.
body_sentences.168: For each utterance in the validation set, we randomly pick one positive and one negative target (i.e., one word that does and one that does not appear in the utterance) that is not a stop word.
body_sentences.169:
To balance the probability of a word being positive or negative, we use each positive target as a negative target for another utterance in the validation
set.
body_sentences.170: The MLP model is trained on the positive and negative examples corresponding to 80% of the utterances in the validation set of each dataset, and evaluated on the remaining 20%.
body_sentences.171: Figure 5 shows the mean accuracy of the MLP on Flickr8K and COCO.
body_sentences.172: All results using features extracted from the model are above chance (0.5), with the average unit activations of the hidden layers yielding the best results (0.65 for Flickr8K on layer 3, and 0.79 for COCO on layer 4).
body_sentences.173: These numbers show that the speech model infers reliable information about word-level blocks from the low-level audio features it receives as input.
body_sentences.174: The observed trend is similar to the previous task: average unit activations on the higher-level hidden layers are more informative for this task than the utterance embeddings, but the performance plateaus before the topmost layer.
body_sentences.175: 4.5 Sentence similarity  Next we explore to what extent the model’s representations correspond to those of humans.
body_sentences.176: We employ the Sentences Involving Compositional Knowledge (SICK) dataset (Marelli et al., 2014).
body_sentences.177:
SICK consists of image descriptions taken from
Flickr8K and video captions from the SemEval 2012 STS MSRVideo Description data set (STS) (Agirre et al., 2012).
body_sentences.178: Captions were paired at random, as well as modified to obtain semantically similar and contrasting counterparts, and the resulting pairs were rated for semantic similarity.
body_sentences.179: For all sentence pairs in SICK, we generate synthetic spoken sentences and feed them to the COCO Speech RHN, and calculate the cosine similarity between the averaged MFCC input vectors, the averaged hidden layer activation vectors, and the sentence embeddings.
body_sentences.180: Z-score transformation was applied before calculating the cosine similarities.
body_sentences.181:
We then correlate these cosine similarities with
• semantic relatedness according to human ratings • cosine similarities according to z-score transformed embeddings from COCO Text RHN • edit similarities, a measure of how similar the sentences are in form, specifically, 1−normalized Levenshtein distance over character sequences
Figure 6 shows a boxplot over 10,000 bootstrap samples for all correlations.
body_sentences.182: We observe that (i) correlation with edit similarity initially increases, then decreases; (ii) correlation with human relatedness scores and text model embeddings increases until layer 4, but decreases for hidden layer 5.
body_sentences.183: The initially increasing and then decreasing correlation with edit similarity is consistent with the findings that information about form is encoded by lower layers.
body_sentences.184:
The overall growing correlation with both human semantic similarity ratings and
the COCO Text RHN indicate that higher layers learn to represent semantic knowledge.
body_sentences.185: We were somewhat surprised by the pattern for the correlation with human ratings and the Text model similarities which drops for layer 5.
body_sentences.186: We suspect it may be caused by the model at this point in the layer hierarchy being strongly tuned to the specifics of the COCO dataset.
body_sentences.187: To test this, we checked the correlations with COCO Text embeddings on validation sentences from the COCO dataset instead of SICK.
body_sentences.188: These increased monotonically, in support of our conjecture.
body_sentences.189: 4.6 Homonym disambiguation  Next we simulate the task of distinguishing between pairs of homonyms, i.e.
body_sentences.190: words with the same acoustic form but different meaning.
body_sentences.191: We group the words in the union of the training and validation data of the COCO dataset by their phonetic transcription.
body_sentences.192: We then pick pairs of words which have the same pronunciation but different spelling, for example suite/sweet.
body_sentences.193: We impose the following conditions: (a) both forms appear more than 20 times, (b) the two forms have different meaning (i.e.
body_sentences.194: they are not simply variant spellings like theater/theatre), (c) neither form is a function word, and (d) the more frequent form constitutes less than 95% of the occurrences.
body_sentences.196: For each pair we generate a binary classification task by taking all the utterances where either form appears, using average input vectors, utterance embeddings, and average unit activations as features.
body_sentences.197: Instances for all feature sets are normalized to unit L2 norm.
body_sentences.198: For each task and feature set we run stratified 10-fold cross validation using Logistic Regression to predict which of the two words the utterance contains.
body_sentences.199: Figure 7 shows, for each pair, the relative error reduction of each feature set with respect to the majority baseline.
body_sentences.200: There is substantial variation across word pairs, but overall the task becomes easier as the features come from higher layers in the network.
body_sentences.201: Some forms can be disambiguated with very high accuracy (e.g.
body_sentences.202: sale/sail, cole/coal, pairs/pears), while some others cannot be distinguished at all (peaking/peeking, great/grate, mantle/mantel).
body_sentences.203: We examined the sentences containing the failing forms, and found out that almost all occurrences of peaking and mantle were misspellings of peeking and mantel, which explains the impossibility of disambiguating these cases.
body_sentences.204: 5 Conclusion  We present a multi-layer recurrent highway network model of language acquisition from visually grounded speech signal.
body_sentences.205: Through detailed analysis we uncover how information in the input signal is transformed as it flows through the network: formal aspects of language such as word identities that not directly present in the input are discovered and encoded low in the layer hierarchy, while semantic information is most strongly expressed in the topmost layers.
body_sentences.206: Going forward we would like to compare the representations learned by our model to the brain activity of people listening to speech in order to determine to what extent the patterns we found correspond to localized processing in the human cortex.
body_sentences.207: This will hopefully lead to a better understanding of language learning and processing by both artificial and neural networks.
body_sentences.208: Acknowledgements  We would like to thank David Harwath for making the Flickr8k Audio Caption Corpus publicly available.
